Hi @rachmadvwp,

's' refers to spikes, and 'x' refers to _spike traces_, which keeps a decaying history of a neuron's most recent spike, implemented as a exponentially decaying quantity which is set to 1 when a spike occurs.

`torch.ger(source_s, target_x)` computes the outer product between spikes in the "source" layer (from which the connection originates) and the spikes traces in the "target" layer (to which the connection connects). So, if the source layer has `n` neurons, and the target layer has `m` neurons, the result of this is a matrix of size `[n, m]`, the same size as the weight matrix connecting the two layers. 

`PostPre` implements the "online" implementation of STDP; see [here](http://www.scholarpedia.org/article/Spike-timing_dependent_plasticity#Online_implementation_of_STDP_models), in particular, see Figure 2.

I know the STDP and the mechanism which is supposed to be implemented in the code.
Since I'm still learning python, I just wanted to ensure whether my guess was correct.
Thanks for the answer, it is really helpful.

Hi @rachmadvwp,

You could define a new learning rule which does this. Take a look at e.g. the [PostPre learning rule](https://github.com/Hananel-Hazan/bindsnet/blob/291eb3e5c2736d7f8842c820dfe41fbdc2fe10d7/bindsnet/learning/__init__.py#L112). A new learning rule can be custom-defined like:

```
from bindsnet.learning import LearningRule

class CustomLearningRule(LearningRule):
    def __init__(self,
        connection: AbstractConnection,
        nu: Optional[Union[float, Sequence[float]]] = None,
        weight_decay: float = 0.0,
        **kwargs
    ) -> None:
        ...

    def _connection_update(self, **kwargs):
        if self.source.s.any() or self.target.s.any():  # This, for example, checks if there are any spikes in the source, target neuron populations.
            ...
```
Something like that. Just fill in your custom code. Let me know if you have any other questions.

Hi @rachmadvwp,

Spike traces are implemented at the [neuron level](https://github.com/Hananel-Hazan/bindsnet/blob/36dcb2610f4f76369c0bd89ea92d2c4ddae42201/bindsnet/network/nodes.py#L92). You can set a layer's spike trace time constant by passing in a custom value for `tc_trace` (short for _trace time constant_), which are in units of milliseconds. For example:

```
from bindsnet.network.nodes import LIFNodes

layer = LIFNodes(n=100, traces=True, tc_trace=100)
```

This creates a layer of 100 LIF neurons which records spike traces that decay to 1/e after 100ms (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_constant), and then 1/e^2 after 200ms, etc.

The default value of `tc_trace` is 20ms, which can be found by reading the doc string.

If you want something different, you can implement a custom `Nodes` object with has a custom spike trace implementation.
